column5: DTI: >85% LTV/CLTV = 45% <=85% LTV/CLTV = 50%  ---         •        If LTV/CLTV > 85% → Max DTI = 45%         •        When the borrower is putting less than 15% down (higher risk), the debt-to-income ratio allowed is capped lower at 45%.         •        If LTV/CLTV ≤ 85% → Max DTI = 50%         •        When the borrower is putting 15% or more down (lower risk), the lender allows a higher DTI up to 50%.
column6: if ltv,cltv>85%, then <=45% if ltv,cltv<=85%, then <=50%
column18: Debt to Income Ratio. A measure lenders use to determine how much of a borrower’s gross monthly income goes toward paying debts. DTI limits depend on LTV & CLTV  Two Types of DTI: 1. Front-End DTI (Housing Ratio) = Proposed Housing Payment (PITIA) / Gross Monthly Income 2. Back-End DTI (Total DTI) = (PITIA + All other monthly debts) / Gross monthly income

column5: Max Cash Out Allowed (may be used to meet reserves)

column1: LTV/CLTV <=70%: Unlimited  ----         •        If LTV/CLTV > 70% → Max Cash-Out = $1,000,000         •        Borrower can only take up to $1M in cash proceeds, even if equity would allow more.         •        Example: Property value $2M, loan balance $400K → theoretically $1M+ equity available. But since new LTV would be >70%, you’re capped at $1M cash out.         •        If LTV/CLTV ≤ 70% → Max Cash-Out = Unlimited

column5: Minimum Reserves - Primary : <=$2,000,000 = 6 months >$2,000,000 = 9 months -----  • If loan amount (or loan size) ≤ $2,000,000 → Minimum Reserves = 6 months  • The borrower must show they have enough liquid assets to cover 6 months of PITIA (Principal, Interest, Taxes, Insurance, and HOA dues if any).  • If loan amount > $2,000,000 → Minimum Reserves = 9 months

column14: Months since the credit event LLPA - (Loan-Level Price Adjustment) is a risk-based fee charged by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac on conventional loans to account for borrower and loan characteristics that increase risk. Factors like a borrower's credit score, loan-to-value (LTV) ratio, and property type influence the LLPA, which can either increase or decrease the interest rate or closing costs. Higher LLPA fees are applied to riskier loans, while lower fees are given to lower-risk borrowers with factors like high credit scores and large down payments

column18: Is Appraisal Valuation Review Required? This depends on CU Score and other factors Related context: A Collateral Desktop Analysis (CDA) is a third-party appraisal review product (usually from providers like Clear Capital, Solidifi, etc.) used by lenders/investors to validate an appraiser’s opinion of value.         •        It’s essentially a desk review of the appraisal.         •        Independent analyst/software compares the appraisal to market data, comps, and trends.         •        Provides a confidence score and sometimes an adjusted value range.  ⸻  How It’s Used in Guidelines         •        Many investors require either:         •        A low CU score (e.g., ≤ 2.5) OR         •        A CDA to support the appraisal.
column20: if icu_score <=2.5 and loan_amount <=$2000000 ,then no,  if cu_score >2.5 or no score and loan_amount <=$2000000 ,then yes (review required for ARR, CCA or CDA, 10% variance allowed),  if loan_amount >$2000000,then Yes (Enhanced desk review (ARR, CCA or CDA) required on lower valued appraisal),  else Yes

Collateral Underwriter score. Collateral Underwriter (CU) is Fannie Mae’s automated appraisal risk assessment tool. It assigns a risk score from 1.0 to 5.0 on every appraisal submitted through the Uniform Collateral Data Portal (UCDP).

column27: Rate/Term Refinance: Acquired ≤ 6 months: The lesser of the current appraisal value or the purchase price plus documented improvements (if any) is used. Acquired > 6 months: The appraised value is used.  Cash-Out Refinance: Acquired > 6 months & < 12 months: The lesser of the current appraisal value or the purchase price plus documented improvements (if any) is used. Acquired > 12 months: The appraised value is used.

column5: Non-Warrantable Condos
yes
column14: A Non-Warrantable Condo = a condominium project that does not meet Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac’s eligibility requirements (“warrantability”).  • “Warrantable” = the condo is eligible for sale to Fannie/Freddie.  • “Non-Warrantable” = ineligible, so it can’t be sold to the agencies.  • That means Conventional financing (Conforming loans) is not allowed → borrowers usually need portfolio loans, non-QM loans, or jumbo financing.

column5: Condotel
no
column14: A Condotel = a condo in a hotel-like building, offering nightly rentals and hotel services. It’s automatically non-warrantable, so borrowers can’t get conventional financing — they need portfolio or non-QM loans, usually with larger down payments.
